hedline.hl1: F.B.I. Investigates Letter Threatening Bombings in City

abstract.p: New York City Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani and Police Comr Bernard B Kerik say that FBI is investigating copies of letter sent to two Midtown Manhattan hotels and The Washington Post that threatened Palestinian bombings of Times Square and other New York locations in early November; but Giuliani says that no orgn claimed credit in letter and that it is unclear how serious a concern it is (S)

block.p: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik said yesterday that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was investigating copies of a letter sent to two Midtown Manhattan hotels and The Washington Post that threatened Palestinian bombings of Times Square and other New York locations in early November.
But Mr. Giuliani said that no organization claimed credit in the letter and that it was unclear how serious a concern it was.

Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik said yesterday that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was investigating copies of a letter sent to two Midtown Manhattan hotels and The Washington Post that threatened Palestinian bombings of Times Square and other New York locations in early November.
But Mr. Giuliani said that no organization claimed credit in the letter and that it was unclear how serious a concern it was.

''The letter contains threats, but at this point there's no indication as to whether or not this is the work of a prankster, or it might be more serious than that,'' Mr. Giuliani said at a news conference in Queens.

Mr. Kerik, who was at the same news conference, said that the city had already increased security because of the recent violence in the Middle East and that it had no plans to add more. ''We've already enhanced security as much as we need to,'' he said.
The F.B.I. outlined its information about the letters in a memo sent to other law enforcement agencies to warn them about possible attacks. The memo was first reported in The New York Post yesterday.

A federal law enforcement official said yesterday that the memo was prepared ''out of an excess of caution.'' A senior police official played down the significance of any threat, adding that ''we get nonspecific threats all the time -- we have to look at all of them.''
Mr. Giuliani said that ''nobody should get unduly alarmed'' about the letters.
